TextEquiv.Unicode: Economic Importance: This major pest of fruit also severely damages forest and ornamental trees. Heavy injury has been observed in Afghanistan and serious damage to birch was caused in 1939-1940 in Uzbekistan, USSR. In Quetta and other areas of West Pakistan, trees on many of the streets have been killed. Holes and small rotting areas on the bark of the main trunk and large branches indicate damage by the Quetta borer. Large parts of the attacked areas eventually fall off. As a result of larval feeding into the bast and sapwood, the sap flow is cut off before it reaches the crown and the tree dies. The galleries and tunnels cause a drying out of the stem and branches so that they break off easily in the wind. Trees are often killed in 2-4 years.

Distribution: Afghanistan, China (mainland--Western Tibet), India (Kashmir), Iran (southeastern), Pakistan (West), USSR (southeastern area including Kazaka- stan, Uzbekistan). Found usually in the lower mountainous areas.
Hosts: Almond, apple, apricots, peach, quince, walnut, elm, poplars, willows, and other trees.

Life History and Habits: Under West Pakistan conditions, the biology is as follows: In May females deposit eggs in groups of 5-10 inside wounds in the bark, pits of stems or broken ends of branches of living trees. One female may lay about 50 eggs which hatch in 10-14 days. At first, the larva feeds on soft bark but later bores into the sapwood where it starts a gallery. During the summer and fall, the larva enlarges the gallery but during the winter it chews out the tunnel. The pupal chamber is constructed the following spring. Pupation requires about 4-5 months but adults remain in the pupal chamber several months until the exoskeleton hardens. Adults appear in May and are numerous in June but decline in July and August. Oviposition occurs about 10 days following mating. The life cycle requires two years.
INSECTS NOT KNOWN TO OCCUR IN THE UNITED STATES
